ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SCIENTISTS AND TECHNOLOGISTS
(Plans to increase number)


    1. Mr Robert Chua Teck Chew asked the Minister for Trade and Industry what are the Government's plans to increase the number of scientists and technologists from our local universities and abroad so as to meet the manpower needs of the public and private sectors' research and development programmes.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, for research and development to bear fruit, the critical success factor is undoubtedly the human factor. It is thus essential that we have sufficient trained and expert manpower. Under our National Technology Plan, we aim to have a ratio of 40 research scientists and engineers (RSEs) per 10,000 labour force by the year 1995. From the 1992 R&D Survey, we now have 37 RSEs per 10,000 labour force.

    The National Science and Technology Board is continuing its efforts to strengthen and develop our R&D talent pool. It does this through programmes to increase public awareness of R&D, the funding of postgraduate study grants, research training and exchange programmes and facilitating the recruitment of foreign R&D talent.

    Whilst our local universities are our main sources of RSE manpower, we need to encourage more of our graduates to enter into research as a career. During the Technology Month held last September, the National Science and Technology Board published newspaper feature articles on our R&D achievements, and conducted seminars, workshops and exhibitions on R&D, together with our universities, polytechnics and research centres and institutes. Many of these events were for students, aimed at stimulating their interest in R&D as a career.

    In addition, the National Science and Technology Board jointly funds, with

Column: 887

private companies, study grants for postgraduate courses in R&D work and technology management, and research training and exchange programmes. These schemes are meant to help companies upgrade their existing R&D workforce, and to encourage companies to train new staff for R&D work.

    Our local universities cannot fully meet demand for researchers by the private and public sectors. Therefore, to supplement our local pool of RSE manpower, particularly in areas where there are insufficient researchers with the required expertise, the National Science and Technology Board works together with EDB to assist companies to recruit from overseas. These well-qualified, experienced researchers bring with them knowledge and skills that we would take years to develop on our own.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin (Nominated Member): Sir, would the Minister consider keeping in view that there is a fair representation of local women in science and technology?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, as in all areas, we recruit purely on merit. If there are any women who have been rejected because they are women, though they have their merits, I will be very pleased to hear and take action. But I think the Member would agree that we should not lower the standards in order to recruit women into R&D manpower.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: I agree with the Minister. But I am wondering whether there are any measures to get women more interested in science and technology because that would be using our manpower and womanpower wisely for the next century.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, all our measures to try and persuade our manpower to go into areas which are useful to our economy are aimed at both the men and women and I want to assure the Member that, having been to the National Science and Technology Board, there is a very high representation of women involved in research.

MINOR TRAFFIC ACCIDENTS
(Investigations)


    2. Mr Choo Wee Khiang asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) whether the Traffic Police investigate cases of minor accidents not involving any injury where there were no independent eye witnesses and Police were not at the scene; and (b) whether the Police can determine which party is at fault, based solely on the reports later made by those involved in the accident.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee)(for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, many motorists are still under the mistaken impression that even for minor accidents where there are no injuries or serious damage, they are required to lodge Police reports. This is not so. (For such minor accidents, the law does not require a police report unless the parties fail to exchange particulars.) As a result, Traffic Police are inundated with tens of thousands of reports of such minor accidents. In 1992 alone, there were 52,471 of such reports. Motorists making these reports expect the Traffic Police to make judgments and allocate blameworthiness and issue summons based purely on these reports. But in most of these cases it is almost impossible for Traffic Police to draw conclusions which will be fair. The reports are made after the parties and vehicles have left the scene and there are no independent witnesses. Almost always, each side making the report categorically asserts that the other is to blame.

    Because of this, Traffic Police has scaled down investigation of such minor accidents and the insurance industry is aware of it. What is important is that in such accidents, the parties should exchange particulars and then report the accident to their respective insurance companies to pursue their insurance claims. This is the position in many other countries, including Australia.

    The Traffic Police will, however, still investigate accidents where there is clear evidence of breaches of the law, incidents of criminal behaviour, such as road bullying, drunken driving, and reckless driving.

SINGAPORE TELECOM SHARES
(Banks undertaking responsibility of stockbrokers)


    3. Mr Chia Shi Teck asked the Minister for Finance whether banks are legally permitted and sufficiently equipped to undertake the role and responsibility of stockbrokers for the Singapore Telecom shares and, if so, whether the precedent is set for banks to deal in more ``selected privatised'' shares in the future.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, the recent public offering of Singapore Telecom (ST) shares is by far the largest flotation in Singapore's corporate history. It attracted the largest number of Singaporean investors with more than 1.4 million Singaporeans subscribing for and being allotted ST's "A" and "B" shares. Before the flotation, there were only about 400,000 investors with CDP securities accounts.

    In anticipation of the large number of people wanting to sell their ST shares during its initial period of trading, special SES trading terminals were set up at 107 branches of local banks located around the island. This is to provide members of the public with easy access to information about ST's share price, and to enable shareholders to sell their shares easily without having to go through a stock broking firm. Besides avoiding over-crowding at the stock broking firms, having the terminals located at various housing estates also reduces inconvenience to the investors, especially the senior citizens. They need not travel personally to the central business district just to sell a couple of hundred shares.

    About 14,750 investors sold their "A" and/or "B" shares on the first day of listing of Singapore Telecom through these special terminals. The existing SES stockbroking firms would not have the capacity to handle such a large number of individual sellers in addition to the usual daily transactions in the other counters.

    These special trading centres are set up specifically to only allow the investor to sell his ST "A" or "B" shares. Staff of the bank manning the terminals are not

Column: 890

required to provide advice to investors on their share investments. Their job is just to key in the sell orders into the trading terminals to match the current best bid in the market. If an investor is unsure whether to sell his Telecom shares, he would be asked to consider the matter carefully before rejoining the queue to sell his shares.

    Singapore adopts the universal banking concept whereby our banks provide a wide range of services to their customers. Banks are exempt dealers under the Securities Industry Act. Accordingly, they are permitted to deal in securities on behalf of third parties. All the local banks have their own subsidiaries which are members of the Stock Exchange. Hence, the branches where the special terminals are located are merely acting as agents of their subsidiaries in carrying out the share transactions.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck (Nominated Member): Sir, if it is simply to facilitate the sale of shares, could there be other better methods, like using the telephone lines, instead of setting up the terminals?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: That may be difficult because you need to confirm a sale transaction and a verbal request may not be sufficient.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck: The second question is whether the banks will play this role for future Government privatisation exercise.

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: It will depend on the Stock Exchange and the size of future offerings.

Mr Robert Chua Teck Chew asked the Minister for Finance, as a result of the successful sales of Singapore Telecom Vendor Shares by Temasek Holdings Pte Ltd to the public, (a) how much was received by Temasek Holdings; (b) how much of the funds received was derived from Central Provident Fund members' accounts; and (c) how does Temasek

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, the net proceeds from Singapore Telecom's initial public offer was about $4 billion.

    The amount withdrawn from CPF members' accounts to purchase Singapore Telecom shares was about $2.18 billion.

    The funds will be reinvested. How this will be done will depend, among other things, on what investment opportunities are available. The expected returns will depend on the nature of the investment, as well as the economic and market conditions prevailing at that time.

SINGAPORE TELECOM GROUP A SHARES
(Reasons for non-application by eligible Singaporeans)


    5. Mr Chia Shi Teck asked the Minister for Communications if he will state (i) the number of eligible Singaporeans who did not apply for the Singapore Telecom Group A shares and (ii) the reason(s) for their non-application.

     The Minister for Communications (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, out of a total of 1,694 million offer letters for Group A shares which were sent out to all eligible Singaporeans, 1.45 million returned their application forms to apply for Singapore Telecom Group A shares. In other words, about 244,000 Singaporeans or 14.4% of those eligible decided not to apply.

    We can only guess as to why this group of Singaporeans decided not to apply for the Group A shares. Some may have had other priorities in the use of their CPF funds. Others may have been averse to the risks of share investment.

Column: 892



    But whatever the case, the Government has left it to the individual to consider and decide, after making available all the relevant information. The fact that more than 85% of eligible Singaporeans did apply is a measure of the success of this exercise to enhance the assets of Singaporeans and make them members of a share-owning society.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck: Sir, could it be that these people have no money to apply and they have missed out on the wealth, especially when the prices of ST shares rise? Or could the Government not give them the shares, as it gave them the $200 under the CPF Top-up Scheme? Out of 800,000, I think something like 600,000 did not even top up with $500. They could be the people who are poor and who do not have the money to top up. You need to have money to apply for the shares.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, first of all, it is not true that people who did not apply for the shares were the ones who did not have money in their CPF. A further breakdown of the numbers would indicate that not all the people who were active CPF account holders applied for the Group A shares. There were actually 10% of active CPF account holders, ie, people who are contributing regularly to their CPF accounts, who did not apply for the Group A shares. As I said, we can only guess as to why these people did not apply for the Group A shares. But the more important point really is that it is a conscious decision on the part of individuals to participate in this exercise. The Government gave $200 under the CPF Top-up Scheme and made the scheme as convenient as possible and it also made the Group A share application as simple as possible. But in spite of all this, 10% of active CPF account holders did not apply.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, first of all, I would like to declare my pecuniary interest. Would Singaporeans who are away overseas, and their relatives have been asked to apply on their behalf for the Group A shares, be allocated such shares?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Yes, there were special arrangements made for eligible

Column: 893

Singaporeans who were overseas. These arrangements were made well in advance. Proxy forms were made available to those who were about to go overseas. These forms were also available to their friends and relatives here in Singapore so that they could be sent or faxed to them. The administrators of the scheme also accepted responses by fax. So it was made as convenient as possible and all those who responded accordingly were allocated the shares.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, as regards the CPF Top-up Scheme, can the Minister tell the House how many new accounts were opened?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid I do not have that number available. But if the Member wishes to address the question to the Minister for Labour, I am sure he will get the answer.

Column: 893

INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERS OF STATUTORY BOARDS
(Adoption of less disruptive method for allocation of shares)


    6. Dr Toh Keng Kiat asked the Minister for Communications whether a less disruptive method will be adopted for future allocation of shares in the initial public offers of statutory boards, including a step-by-step education on electronic share application on television and video demonstrations in community centres.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government adopted various measures to facilitate a smooth initial public offering (IPO) of Singapore Telecom shares.

    Firstly, there was an extensive publicity campaign which began five months before the IPO. The Stock Exchange of Singapore (SES) and the banks organised a series of share investment seminars to educate the public on the mechanics of share investment. This was reinforced by the "Invest Singapore" publicity campaign, which included mobile exhibitions to 15 community centres all over the island to educate the public on the risks and benefits, as well as the procedures of share investment. The banks and the

Column: 894

Stock Exchange of Singapore were also present at these exhibitions to facilitate the opening of CPF investment accounts and CDP accounts.

    Secondly, the Government simplified the application and selling procedures for Group A shares. An offer letter was sent to all eligible Singaporeans who merely had to sign and return the form in order to apply for Group A shares. The fact that 1.45 million Singaporeans, or more than 85% of all eligible Singaporeans, applied for Group A shares with minimum hassle indicates that the simplified application procedures for Group A shares were effective

    Unlike Group A shares, Group B shares were fixed-price shares with no discount or loyalty shares, similar to those offered in the fixed-price tranche of other IPOs. There are established application procedures for such shares. These shares were meant to cater for those Singaporeans who wanted some more Singapore Telecom shares. The anticipated target group was the existing share investors, who already have trading accounts with their brokers and CDP accounts, as well as new investors who are serious enough to learn and follow the established procedures.

    Response to Group B shares was unexpectedly overwhelming. Furthermore, many Singaporeans waited till the last moment to open the necessary accounts, despite the early publicity for the listing. The result was long queues at the CDP and the CPF agent banks. SES then simplified application procedures so that those using cash need not open CDP accounts, and those using CPF funds need not explicitly transfer funds from the CPF Ordinary Accounts to their investment accounts. Unfortunately, before we could implement these changes, some minor incidents of unruly crowd behaviour occurred at the CDP and CPF agent banks. Once the changes were implemented, the queues disappeared.

    We also anticipated a rush of people wanting to sell ST shares when trading began. We therefore made arrangements for Singaporeans to sell Group A and B

Column: 895

shares at designated bank branches as well as at stockbroking offices and simplified the procedures for doing so. As matters turned out, these arrangements were more than adequate. There were no queues or delays, and everything went on smoothly.

    Sir, ST was the largest IPO ever on the SES. Its listing was not only a financial exercise, but also a political one to distribute share ownership among as many citizens as possible. Overnight, the number of shareholders in Singapore has increased more than three-fold, from about 400,000 to over 1.4 million. Despite this, overall, the operation proceeded extremely smoothly. Credit for this is due to the banks, SES, the CPF Board, ST itself, as well as the many Government departments which helped to coordinate and execute the operation. Their staff worked long hours to make everything ready and to service the public. The Government thanks them for all their invaluable contributions, without which the exercise would not have been possible.

    The Government will study the lessons learnt from this first IPO of a privatised statutory board, including Dr Toh's suggestion of a more comprehensive education on electronic share application procedures. Nevertheless, the fact that so many Singaporeans have been involved in this exercise will, to a large extent, ensure a smoother implementation the next time round.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Cheng San GRC): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether the Government would consider an opt-out system or scheme for future IPOs? If the answer is affirmative, may I further ask the Minister how the Government would tackle (1) the legal issues relating to such a scheme and (2) the political odium of such a system should the share price upon listing be lower than the issued price since the scheme works on the basis of a passive acceptance.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, an opt-out scheme was one of the options considered in the Singapore Telecom IPO. But the Government decided on an opt-in scheme instead. The decision to invest

Column: 896

should be one made by the individual, not by Government. Government can explain the benefits of long-term share ownership. Government can make the procedures as simple and as convenient as possible, but it is up to the individual to decide whether he wants to invest in Singapore Telecom shares or not. An opt-in scheme requires the individual to make such a conscious and deliberate decision. An opt-out scheme does not.

    We are prepared to consider an opt-out scheme for future privatisations if the experience of the Singapore Telecom exercise had shown that the opt-in scheme that we adopted was too cumbersome, or discouraged too many Singaporeans from taking up the Singapore Telecom Group A shares. However, this did not happen. Of the over 1.6 million forms that we sent out, 1.45 million Singaporeans applied for and were allocated Group A shares, as I mentioned earlier. As a result of the simplified and convenient procedures for application, the whole exercise proceeded smoothly. So the Government will continue to use the opt-in scheme for future privatisation exercises.

     Dr Toh Keng Kiat (Nominated Member): Sir, is the Minister aware that there were complaints by some successful applicants for the Group C tranche that there was a delay in the confirmation of these shares which caused them to lose the opportunity of being able to trade in the shares on the first trading day?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I believe there were some complaints of this nature. But again, as I said, this was a massive exercise. It was a very large exercise. There were many people involved and I think the processing of all the various tranches of shares was done as quickly as possible. Staff involved in the banks, CPF and SES worked through the night to try and get the results out as quickly as possible. Under the circumstances, I am sure that there were some people who might have been left out or were informed late about their allocation of shares. But I believe that these matters were being handled by the agent banks as expeditiously as possible.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Sale of flat before five years)


    7. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for National Development under what circumstances can a purchaser of a Housing and Development Board flat sell the flat upon taking possession without the need to wait for five years.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang) (for the Minister for National Development): Under the HDB's Home Ownership Scheme, a purchaser of a HDB flat has to complete a requisite occupation period before he can sell the flat in the open market. The requisite occupation period is five years if the flat is bought directly from HDB and 30 months if it is bought in the open market.

    However, the following categories of flat owners are allowed to sell their flats in the open market without completing the requisite occupation period. The first category are owners of 1-room and 2-room flats. The second category are owners of 3-, 4-, 5- and Executive flats who qualify to sell their flats under the Third Child Priority (TCP) Scheme, and the third category are owners of HUDC flats.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, I want to clarify with the Minister whether, under these three categories, a purchaser can immediately upon taking possession sell the flat in the open market? Or must he sell it back to the HDB?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: I thought my answer states specifically that owners of these categories are allowed to sell their flats in the open market.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: And are they required to pay a levy on the sale price? If so, how much?

    Second, it will give patients medically essential and cost-effective treatment of proven value for illness.

Column: 952



    Third, the treatment will be delivered without frills, that is, the use of space and other physical amenities will be very economical and the nursing staff to patient ratio will be adequate.

    Fourth, the treatment will be by trained personnel of qualified doctors, specialists and other medical staff working as a team.

    Fifth, the treatment will use appropriate diagnostic and treatment facilities; drugs provided will be from a standard list which is more extensive than that recommended by the World Health Organisation.

    And lastly, the treatment will include use of intensive care unit beds. Intensive care unit beds are not classified by classes and are open to patients purely according to medical need.

    This basic package will not include treatment for certain conditions. For example, it will not include cosmetic surgery or cosmetic dentistry other than for burns and injuries or those that are required on medical grounds. It will not include sex change operations, IVF treatment, organ and bone marrow transplants (other than kidney transplants). These excluded treatments account for less than 0.1% of the cases dealt with in the unsubsidised wards. Experimental drugs not of proven value and other high cost investigations and treatment where effective cheaper alternatives are available, will also be excluded. Doctors have treatment protocols to guide them in treating individual patients. In some situations, ordering more investigations and treatments will not improve the patient's quality of life significantly or change the outcome. Examples are treatment of incurable diseases where there is no chance of survival, or using life support systems to prolong death. Under the basic package, patients in these situations will be treated humanely, be relieved of pain and suffering, made comfortable and allowed to retain their human dignity.

    The basic package cannot be fixed for all time. The Government will continually review and revise the basic package to take into account medical progress such as new drugs, procedures and equipment, and social and economic progress.

Column: 953



    A large part of basic health care will be provided in the polyclinics and by hospitals which receive Government subsidies.

    All subsidised hospitals will compete with each other on price and quality, even though some of them will have specialist departments which the others will not. When hospitals are not subject to market forces, the potential for waste and inefficiency is enormous. Competition will improve their services and make them more responsive to market signals.

    But free competition alone will not guarantee us an optimal health service. Health care is an example of market failure. The Government must intervene directly to regulate key aspects of the health care system to prevent over-supply of medical services and dampen demand.

    In health care, supply creates its own demand. More supply and more competition does not always lead to lower cost or better services. More supply can actually increase demand and cost because of the nature of the consumer. The consumer who pays the bill, that is, the patient or a member of the family, is usually worried, under great emotional stress and is in no position to weigh the advice of doctors and make a rational choice based on the likely efficacy of the treatment and on his ability to pay. The consumer is often uninformed or misinformed, and naively believes that the more expensive the doctor, drug or procedure, the greater the likelihood of a cure. If the family is paying, their love, filial piety, and loyalty can be called into question if they do not agree to order the most expensive or latest procedures. This situation opens the door for health care providers to order more tests, procedures and expensive drugs. Often the patients or relatives themselves may request for these because they have read somewhere or heard from someone about these new medical developments. It is not mere chance that countries with more doctors, especially specialists, tend to spend more on health care.

    Government must therefore not only define the basic medical package. It also

Column: 954

has to prevent over-supply of medical services by regulating the supply of doctors, specialists, beds in subsidised hospitals and the establishment of specialist and sub-specialist disciplines and the purchase of expensive high-tech equipment. These are described in the White Paper.

    In keeping with the primary mission of subsidised hospitals to provide for the lower- and middle-income groups, all subsidised hospitals will have C Class wards to serve the most needy Singaporeans. A minimum of 65% of the beds will be B2, B2+ and C Class beds.

    There will be some unsubsidised wards, Class A wards, not exceeding 11% of the total beds in these hospitals. These will be for patients who want more personalised care, creature comforts and non-essential services, and are prepared to pay the full cost for them. Patients in Class A wards pay the full cost not only of the extras, but also the full cost of the basic essential medical care.

    I know that some people are uncomfortable that patients in Government and restructured hospitals can get medical care beyond the basic package by paying more. They are especially unhappy that in the same Government or restructured hospital, patients in Class C wards should have spartan facilities, while others in A Class wards enjoy more privacy and creature comforts. They prefer everyone, rich or poor, to have exactly the same standard of medical care.

    This is a natural, egalitarian, human instinct. But, unfortunately, complete equality of treatment is neither realistic nor desirable. Logically, there are only two ways for everyone to receive exactly the same medical treatment: either the Government must not allow anybody to obtain more medical treatment than the basic package, or else the Government must provide everyone with all the medical treatment he or she wants, without limit.

    The first is an unnecessary and unjustifiable infringement on the personal freedom of individuals. The basic package only defines what the Government will

Column: 955

subsidise and make affordable to the population as a whole. If a patient wants medical treatment which the Government does not consider basic, and the Government will not pay for, why should we stop the patient from getting it if he is prepared to pay for it? What moral right do we have to stop him? We will not make other Singaporeans better off by preventing a well-off patient from getting extra or better treatment. If a patient wants more nursing attention, a private room of his own instead of an open ward, or additional medical tests to confirm a diagnosis which is not really in doubt, and he is prepared to pay for it in full, who is the Government to say no?

    Even granted this, some may still question whether the extra service should be provided in Government and restructured hospitals. If it is not provided in these hospitals, patients can go to private hospitals. If we disallow Singapore hospitals or private hospitals in Singapore from providing such services, patients can travel abroad for treatment. From the point of view of the C and B2 Class patients, it is better in fact for the Government and restructured hospitals to have A Class patients because A Class patients provide a check on the quality of the doctors and the quality of the hospital. These patients are prepared to pay the full cost in the hospital, even though they can afford alternatives like going to a private hospital. If only subsidised patients go to the Government or restructured hospital for treatment, we do not know whether they are going there because the service is good, or because there is no alternative. But if some patients want to be admitted to these hospitals for non-subsidised treatment, then we can be more confident that the hospitals, specialists and staff are competent, and that the hospital is providing good service. We still need to make sure that these specialists and staff are not neglecting the subsidised patients in favour of the non-subsidised patients, but that is a management problem which we can solve.

    The second alternative, that is, providing everyone with all the medical treatment that he or she wants, will bankrupt us. Where do we draw the line?

Column: 956

Should hospital in-patients receive four-star hotel treatment? Can every routine operation be done by the top surgeon? Should every patient who complains of a headache be given a CT scan? The list is endless and unaffordable.

    In every other area of life, people accept that there is a difference between the essentials and the extras and luxuries. There is a big difference between a healthy square meal and a gourmet dinner. People accept that only the well-to-do can afford a gourmet dinner. There is a difference between a 3-room HDB flat and an Executive flat. People accept that only those who are better off can afford an Executive flat. Medical services cannot escape the same logic.

    We need to also ensure that subsidised hospitals keep their costs, and hence their charges, down. Under normal market conditions, we can, after determining the subsidies to the hospital, leave it to competition to keep prices down. But as I explained just now, such self-regulation by market forces does not work because of market failure. Even with Medisave, which is the patient's own savings, patients are more ready to spend their Medisave balances than if they had to pay cash. Hospitals can, therefore, pass higher costs to patients by prescribing more tests and treatments than necessary, or by simply raising charges without losing patients.

    The Ministry of Health will therefore control the revenue per patient day by class of ward, by specialties (for example, oncology cases will have a higher cap than paediatric cases), and by type of hospitals (tertiary hospitals will have higher caps than secondary hospitals). The hospital's revenue, comprising subsidies and the charge to patients, cannot exceed this cap. If it does, the Government will recover the excess. This will encourage hospitals to keep their charges down without restricting too tightly how much they can charge individual patients. Hospitals which reduce their costs can keep their savings and improve their services. Those hospitals which cut costs and reduce service or quality to unacceptable levels

Column: 957

will lose patients and will earn less fees as well as less subsidies. But those which strike the right balance between cost control and service will attract more patients and earn more fees and subsidies.

    Let me now come to financing. How patients pay for health care is an important part of any health care system. Note that the operative term is how, not who pays. Who pays is quite clear. As I have explained earlier, no matter who pays for health care in the first instance, the burden is ultimately borne by the people. The real issue is not who pays, but how and when the payment is made. We must have a system that encourages people to use health care economically and encourages health care providers to minimise inefficiency, minimise costs and prevent over-servicing.

    Under Medisave, individual savings form the core of the system. Government subsidies and catastrophic insurance, that is, MediShield, play supporting roles. Patients pay part of the costs at point of consumption. This applies even to the heavily subsidised C Class wards. Patients who demand higher levels of service must pay more. This ensures that they use medical services only when they really need to. We thus avoid the danger of unlimited demand for "free" medical services.

    The disadvantage of relying exclusively on savings to meet health care costs is that individuals will need to save more for their medical expenses than they are likely to spend because they must be prepared for unexpected contingencies. High Medisave also increases the temptation for patients to draw more on these balances than they absolutely need to. As I pointed out just now, patients are more prepared to spend their Medisave than if they were to pay cash although the Medisave balances are their own money.

    This is why our Medisave system has an insurance component in MediShield. It is catastrophic health insurance incorporating deductibles and co-payments, ie,

Column: 958

deductibles in that the insurance cover starts only after the patient has spent a certain amount, and co-payment in that even after the insurance cover becomes effective, the patient has to share part of the cost.

    For those who have exhausted their Medisave and MediShield or for some good reason cannot even pay C Class rates, Medifund provides a safety net. Medisave, MediShield and Medifund, together with the Government subsidies, ensure that no Singaporean is deprived of medical care.

    Private medical insurance policies generally do not provide for deductibles and co-payments. They also do not restrict what health care providers can charge. Fortunately, the market in private medical insurance is small. But it is growing rapidly. We should act now to guide the growth of the market in the right direction. In the meantime, we can improve our MediShield system in various ways. We can extend the benefits package of MediShield to provide more cover for Class B2 and C treatment by reducing somewhat the deductible amounts. We can also introduce MediShield II for those who want increased daily reimbursement rates so that they can afford higher class wards. MediShield II will be a voluntary opt-in system, unlike the present MediShield which is an opt-out scheme.

    When the private sector insurance policies have the same safeguards as MediShield, we can allow people to use Medisave to pay the premiums of approved private insurance schemes.

    The White Paper also proposes that employers who provide medical benefits to their employees should contribute additional amounts to the employee's Medisave in lieu of part of the medical benefits in kind. We will encourage but not force them to do so. The Government, as the largest employer, will set the example. The Minister for Finance will present the medical benefits package for civil servants.

    Now, let me say something about Medisave in the private sector. Many

Column: 959

patients in the private hospitals use Medisave to pay private hospital and specialist fees.

    We want the private sector to play an increasing role in health care though Government subsidised hospitals will be the dominant component in our health care system. This is why we are limiting A class beds in subsidised hospitals to 11% of the beds in these hospitals. Government will also encourage private sector hospital development by selling suitable sites for such purposes.

    But we need to have some control on the private sector charges as the private and public sector markets are interlinked. The public sector has had to increase the salaries of its doctors and other medical staff, partly because incomes in the private sector increased steadily, especially after Medisave was introduced and widened the gap between the earnings in the private and public sectors. This contributed to the overall rise in health costs. We, therefore, have to control private sector fees and charges when Medisave is used.

    We will work out schemes to limit balance billing of Medisave patients by private hospitals and doctors. This will be the private sector equivalent of the revenue cap system in the subsidised hospitals. There will be a limit on how much cash patients can be asked to pay over and above the payment from Medisave. 74% of the patients treated by private hospitals and doctors use Medisave to pay part of their bills. Income from Medisave patients constitutes 50% to 60% of private doctors' total earnings (I am talking about doctors who service hospitals, not the GPs who cannot draw on Medisave). Limits on balance billing should, therefore, be quite effective in keeping down fee and cost increases in the private medical sector.

    If the patient does not use Medisave and pays the entire bill in cash, the limit will not apply. But patients, we know, are more restrained when they have to pay in cash and will, therefore, resist high charges more strongly.

    We did not invent this idea of limits on balance billing. Germany and Japan have

Column: 960

similar schemes to control private sector charges. We will take some time to develop a comprehensive system of limits on balance billing but a start will be made some time next year.

    Research and development. Our health policy emphasises primary health care, a good basic health package for all at the secondary and tertiary level at affordable prices and sustained cost control measures at all levels. Cost consciousness must become a deep part of the culture of our health care givers.

    Our research and development efforts in medicine and training of doctors must be consistent with and subordinate to the national health policy.

    Ever since the establishment of the Medical School in 1905 in Singapore, the medical profession has attracted the best minds in Singapore and the then Malaya. It is not surprising, therefore, that the quality of our medical service is the best in the region. It is also natural for the medical profession and for Singaporeans to expect us to be in the forefront when introducing or testing new medical procedures and drugs, and to be a leading centre for medical research and development. In the past, before the current explosion in experimental medical work, our society could bear the cost of such ambitions. The majority of the population was deeply suspicious of hospitals so that experimental work in hospitals did not result in an immediate demand for more services.

    The situation has, however, changed. Our population is now alert to the latest medical advances, however tentative, in the medical world. A short report in the newspapers of some new work results in immediate inquiries and demand for the same type of treatment, whether it is a new treatment for cancer, or a new surgical procedure for heart patients. Research with clinical implications, therefore, results in an immediate demand for more health services.

    If we want to maintain our excellent health care system and continue to attract some of our brightest students to study medicine, then we must carry on doing

Column: 961

medical research and development. But we should focus more sharply on research with cost effective practical applications and research which can help improve the health care system. We must not be too ambitious to be at the cutting edge of medical technology. We can also do more theoretical research, like that done in the Institute of Molecular and Cell Biology, which is significant research, but has no immediate impact on the demand for health care services. But we should be very careful in undertaking research in areas not within the basic health care package. For example, we should leave it to other countries with more resources to experiment in organ transplantations.

    The White Paper proposes the establishment of a National Medical Research Council which will approve, oversee and coordinate medical research which has clinical implications.

    The content and emphasis in medical education too must be in line with the national health policy. Undergraduate training must emphasise primary health care, not high-tech medicine. The aim must be to train students to be good family doctors. In postgraduate and specialist training, the aim should be to meet the service needs of the public sector hospitals.

    The National University of Singapore will work together with the Ministry of Health and the Singapore Medical Council to keep undergraduate curriculum current and relevant. The Ministry of Health, together with an Advisory Committee on Medical Specialists, will regulate the training of specialists.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there was a time, not so long ago, when few Singaporeans dared to venture into a hospital. To be sent to hospital was considered by many to be a death sentence. A more educated and affluent people now know the value of early attention and treatment. Fears and inhibition about hospital treatment have diminished. People know more about the latest treatments and advances in medical technology, though often their knowledge is partial and even distorted. All these will

Column: 962

raise the demand for health care. We must learn to spend the money that we set aside for health care wisely.

    The Government undertakes to make a package of essential and effective treatment available to all, not for free, but at affordable prices. It will institute various measures to keep down national health care costs. But the responsibility rests on each of us, as individual Singaporeans, to do all that we can to stay healthy, to save to pay a share of the cost of treatment when we fall ill, and to spend these savings wisely.

    We have a good health care system. The proposals in the White Paper will improve it further. Singaporeans must be sensible about what they can expect from the health care system. Then the Government can manage the system rationally, and not dodge tough choices which are unavoidable. That way, we avoid the awful trauma that the developed countries are going through to reform their health care systems and make them affordable to society.

Not only the private hospitals have adjusted their fees upwards, Government and restructured hospitals have also increased their fees in order to meet the increasing costs and to prevent a brain drain.

Column: 963



    Some people feel that it is the responsibility of the Government to account for the rising cost of medical fees. But I think when people talk about this issue they are very emotional. They do not quite understand the circumstances that have led to this situation and they listen to hearsay and follow what others are complaining about and blame the Government.

Column: 964



    This shows the basic principles and the right direction of the Government to make everybody responsible for his own health. I think we should be very calm and try not to be emotional in drawing the wrong conclusions. I hope that after the debate in this House, people in Singapore will have a better and more comprehensive understanding of our health care system.

    On market forces, theoretically, free market and competition are closely related with the two following features:

    First, we have a lot of buyers and sellers in the market and the individual buying and selling are very small which cannot influence prices.

    Secondly, there is no restriction on buyers and sellers and they understand the market price and related matters. I think Dr Ow has already told me this.

    Nobody can monopolise the prices if there is a balance between supply and demand. President Kennedy of the United States said previously that the free market is not only a more efficient determinant than the best central planning agency, it is also a pillar of the US democratic system. If the free market system is that good, then there would not be so many economic problems in the US. There will not be a wide gap between the rich and the poor and there would not be any inflation in the US. To ensure that, as the Minister has said, the patients do not know the good and bad points of medical treatment and they have no time to choose which hospital, which expert or specialist to see. I think the moral and ethics of doctors are important factors that will determine medical costs. So I hope that the Medical School in Singapore, in addition to inculcating and imparting the medical expertise, should also inculcate the correct attitudes and moral values to relieve people from pain and suffering in the service of society and for the benefit of mankind.

Column: 965

administrative and other staff. But the increase in staff means more expenditure and that will increase operating costs. On the contrary, if the Government wishes to save money by cutting down staff, then the workers will have a heavy responsibility. Morale will be down and the quality of service will also be affected.     On community hospitals, I think Mr Chandra Das also said sometime ago that the number of A class beds should be further reduced in community hospitals, because such hospitals are set up to provide affordable health care services and A class beds are not affordable.

    Workers' welfare and Medisave. The employers do not want their employees to over-use their medical benefits. This is a good measure but we should look further into it because it may be unfair to some people.     Those people who have hereditary diseases such as diabetes need more medical care. It is not because they do not care about their own health. It is because of their own hereditary reasons and not because they neglect their health. So they need medical care. So the question of how these costs could be distributed fairly should be looked into further. I endorse the Government's view that everybody must be responsible for his own health. I think we must pay attention to this. The Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Education have worked out a

Column: 967

scheme to encourage people to take care of their diet by eating less sugar and drinking more water. I think this is a very good way of looking after the health of people.

    But apparently, the White Paper has not dealt in detail about preventive health care. I think the Ministry of Health might already have something in mind. I hope that this can be published in due course. Prevention is better than cure. Before the situation gets out of hand, we should think of preventive measures, and this is consistent with the style of the Government. The White Paper is a good example. Column: 968

impaired, resulting in the health care system in some countries getting totally out of control.

treatment must remain more or less at par between the patients of those two wards, and this the Government should ensure.
